'''Employee voice''' refers to the participation of employees in influencing organisational decision making. Because research and analysis have grown around the voice concept in a variety of disciplines, ‘employee voice’ has become an elastic term meaning somewhat different things to different policy, academic and practitioner actors. In the many disciplines that cover voice, such as human resource management, political science, economics, organisational behaviour, psychology or law, perspectives toward the concept differ. Drawing on Dundon et al. voice can be seen with different lenses. First, voice is an articulation of individual dissatisfaction or concern that aims to address a specific problem or issue with management. Second, voice takes the form of collective organisation, where voice provides a countervailing source of power to management. Third, there is the role of voice as a contribution to management decision-making. Here the purpose is to gain employee input to improve work organisation and efficiency more generally, perhaps through quality circles or teamwork, or eliciting workforce engagement. Fourth, voice can be seen as an instrument for mutual gain, with productive collaboration between capital and labour increasing the long-term viability of an organisation and economic well-being of employees. The editors of the Elgar Handbook of Employee Voice <ref>Wilkinson A.Dundon ,Donaghey J and R.Freeman (2014) The Handbook of employee voice, Elgar</ref> define employee voice as the ways and means through which employees attempt to have a say and potentially influence organisational affairs about issues that affect their work and the interests of managers and owners. This definition combines a variety of voice mechanisms that analysts often group in separate boxes (e.g. involvement or bargaining; union and non-union). It allows for employer implemented Non-union Employee Representative (NER) systems as a collective form of voice, be it chosen to marginalise a union presence or to provide an alternative to union influence In general, employee voice is about how employees are able to have a say over work activities and decisions within the organizations in which they work, regardless of the institutional channel through which it operates—whether through speak-up programmes, quality circles, teamwork, or collective negotiation.
Arguments for employee voice can be both moral and political as well as economic.<ref>Johnstone, S and Ackers, P (2015), Finding a Voice at Work? New Perspectives on Employment Relations, Oxford, Oxford University Press</ref> There are a wide range of mechanisms related to employee voice, and these may be direct or indirect, formal or informal, and power-centred or task-centred. As well as trade union representation, voice may refer to a wide array of techniques including Empowerment, Employee Engagement and Teamworking initiatives. In reality, many employers adopt a blend of voice mechanisms. However, some employers may also wish to limit employee voice, believing instead that the best approach is for management to command and control the organisation. Equally, some employees may not want to have their voice heard, or may not want to express their thoughts.
In July 2013, an international workshop on the benefits of employee voice was organised by Dr Andrew R Timming, an employee voice scholar based at the University of St Andrews. The workshop, entitled, 'Strengthening Democracy at Work', brought together the world's leading employee voice researchers, including: Peter Ackers (University of Loughborough), John Budd (University of Minnesota), Tony Dundon (National University of Ireland, Galway), Stewart Johnstone (University of Newcastle), Andrew Pendleton (York University) and Andrew Timming (University of St Andrews). Also present were several practitioners. The workshop was funded by the Scottish Universities Insight Institute and the Russell Trust. The first day took place in Glasgow and the second day was held at New Lanark. The workshop participants discussed the benefits of employee voice for employees, organisations and societies. In short, when employers give employees a 'say' in the strategic direction of the organisation, all three levels benefit.
== Informal and formal mechanisms == Employee voice is attained through both informal and formal mechanisms. Informal employee voice mechanisms include general conversation between employees and employers, email communication, employee feedback, social functions and meetings at the workplace. Employees can also influence corporate decision making through their actions, such as turnover and absenteeism<ref name="McLean, P 2008">McLean, P (2008), Employee Voice, MGMT341, International and Comparative [[Human resource management|Human Resource Management]], [[University of Wollongong]], delivered 19 August 2008</ref>
Formal mechanisms include communication tools implemented by an organisations human resource department, such as employee surveys and [[suggestion box]]es. Some organisations promote employee voice through financial participation, such as share ownership and [[Profit sharing|profit-sharing]] opportunities. Employee consultative committees and representation through [[trade union]]s are also formal ways of ensuring employees are informed and are given a voice in decisions that affect their employment<ref name="McLean, P 2008"/>
== European Works Councils == In an international context, the role of employee voice varies immensely. The European model is fundamentally based on employee communication and consultation between employees and [[Management|corporate management]]. European [[Works council|Works Councils]] were introduced through the European Directive 1994 to accommodate these goals and provided employees with an opportunity to gain access to senior levels of their employers. The European model has required amendments to improve its effectiveness in managing employee voice and legal compliance<ref>Timming, A (2007), ‘European Works Councils and the Dark Side of Managing Worker Voice’, Human Resource Management Journal, Vol.17, Iss.3, pp.248-254</ref>

{{For|the demon|Eurynomos}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Euronymous | image = Dead and Euronymous.jpg | landscape = yes | caption = [[Per "Dead" Ohlin|Dead]] (left) and Euronymous ('''right''') | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = Øystein Aarseth | alias = | birth_date = 22 March 1968 | birth_place = [[Egersund]], [[Norway]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1993|8|10|1968|3|22|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] | instrument = Guitar | genre = {{flatlist| *[[Black metal]] *[[extreme metal]]}} | occupation = [[Musician]], [[Record producer|producer]] | years_active = 1984–1993 | label = [[Deathlike Silence Productions]] | associated_acts = [[Mayhem (band)|Mayhem]], [[Burzum]], L.E.G.O., Checker Patrol, Horn | website = }} '''Øystein Aarseth''' ({{IPA-no|ˈœʏstæɪn ˈɔʂət|lang}}; 22 March 1968 – 10 August 1993),{{cite web|url=http://i838.photobucket.com/albums/zz310/chagrynn/Euronymous_passport_1.jpg|title=Euronymous' passport|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2018}} better known by his stage name '''Euronymous''', was a [[Norwegians|Norwegian]] [[guitarist]]. Euronymous was a founder of and central figure in the [[early Norwegian black metal scene]]. He was a co-founder of the Norwegian black metal band [[Mayhem (band)|Mayhem]] and was the only constant member from the band's formation in 1984 until his death in 1993. He was also founder and owner of the extreme metal [[record label]] [[Deathlike Silence Productions]] and record shop Helvete. Euronymous professed to be a [[Theistic Satanism|Satanist]] and was known for making extreme [[Misanthropy|misanthropic]] statements. He presented himself as leading a militant [[cult]]-like group known as the "Black Metal Inner Circle." In August 1993, he was murdered by fellow musician [[Varg Vikernes]]. ==Biography== ===1984–1991=== [[File:Øystein Aarseth (Euronymous).jpg|thumb|Euronymous in 1987]] Aarseth formed Mayhem in 1984 along with bassist [[Necrobutcher|Jørn "Necrobutcher" Stubberud]] and drummer [[Kjetil Manheim]]. At the time he was going by the stage name Destructor but later changed his name to Euronymous,{{cite book |title=Metalion: The Slayer Mag Diaries |last=Kristiansen |first=Jon |year=2011 |publisher=Bazillion Points Books |location= |isbn= |page=39 |url= |accessdate=}} derived from the demon [[Eurynomos]] which had inspired the [[Hellhammer]] song of the same name. In summer 1986, Euronymous, Necrobutcher and [[Metalion|Jon "Metalion" Kristiansen]] visited the German [[thrash metal]] band [[Assassin (band)|Assassin]] and recorded the ''Metalion in the Park'' demo under the name Checker Patrol, Metalion contributing background vocals to the title song "Metalion in the Park."Kristiansen, p. 53. In 1988, [[Per "Dead" Ohlin]] became Mayhem's vocalist and [[Jan Axel Blomberg|Jan Axel "Hellhammer" Blomberg]] became its drummer. By 1991, Dead, Euronymous and Hellhammer were living in a house in the woods near [[Kråkstad]], which was used as a place for the band to rehearse.{{cite video |people=Stefan Rydehed (director) |year=2008 |title=Pure Fucking Mayhem |url= |format= |medium=motion picture |publisher=Index Verlag}} Mayhem bassist Necrobutcher said that, after living together for a while, Dead and Euronymous "got on each other's nerves a lot" and "weren't really friends at the end." Hellhammer recalls that Dead once went outside to sleep in the woods because Euronymous was playing synth music that Dead hated. Euronymous then went outside and began shooting into the air with a shotgun.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 52. [[Varg Vikernes]] claims that Dead once stabbed Euronymous with a knife.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 57. On 8 April 1991, Dead was found dead by Euronymous at his home with slit wrists and a [[shotgun]] wound to the head. Dead's death was considered [[suicide]]. Before calling the police, he went to a shop and bought a disposable camera with which he photographed the body, after rearranging some items.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 49. One of these photographs was later used as the cover of a bootleg live album: ''[[Dawn of the Black Hearts]]''.[http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/hh-sod.htm ''Sounds of Death'' magazine (1998): Hellhammer interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823184150/http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/hh-sod.htm |date=23 August 2007 }} Necrobutcher recalls how Euronymous told him of the suicide:
Øystein called me up the next day ... and says, "Dead has done something really cool! He killed himself". I thought, have you lost it? What do you mean cool? He says, "Relax, I have photos of everything". I was in shock and grief. He was just thinking how to exploit it. So I told him, "OK. Don't even fucking call me before you destroy those pictures".{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Campion |title=In the Face of Death |date=20 February 2005 |publisher=[[Guardian Unlimited]] |url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,11710,1419364,00.html |work=[[The Observer]] |accessdate=6 October 2007}}
Euronymous used Dead's suicide to foster Mayhem's "evil" image and claimed Dead had killed himself because death metal had become "trendy" and commercialized.''Lords of Chaos'', pp. 59–60. In time, rumors spread that Euronymous had made a [[stew]] with bits of Dead's brain and had made [[necklace]]s with bits of his skull.{{cite video|people=Michael Dome (director) |year=2007 |title=Murder Music: Black Metal |url=http://www.rockworld.tv/MurderMusicPlayer.html |format= |medium=motion picture |publisher=Rockworld TV |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014183138/http://rockworld.tv/MurderMusicPlayer.html |archivedate=14 October 2007 |df=dmy }} The band later denied the former rumor but confirmed that the latter was true. Moreover, Euronymous claimed to have given these necklaces to musicians he deemed worthy,{{cite video |people=Sam Dunn (director) |year=2005 |title=[[Metal: A Headbanger's Journey]] |url= |format= |medium=motion picture |publisher=Seville Pictures}} which was confirmed by several other members of the scene, like [[Faust (musician)|Bård "Faust" Eithun]]''Lords of Chaos'', p. 55. and Metalion.Kristiansen, p. 219. Necrobutcher later speculated that taking the photographs and forcing others to see them was a way for Euronymous to cope with the shock of seeing his friend dead.{{cite video |people=Martin Ledang (director), Pål Aasdal (director) |year=2007 |title=Once Upon a Time in Norway |url= |format= |medium=motion picture |publisher=Another World Entertainment}} He claimed that Euronymous "went into a fantasy world." Faust of [[Emperor (band)|Emperor]] believes that Dead's suicide "marked the point at which, under Euronymous' direction, the black metal scene began its obsession with all things satanic and evil." Kjetil Manheim said that, after the suicide, Euronymous "tried to be as extreme as he had talked about." The suicide caused a rift between Euronymous and some of his friends, who were disgusted by his attitude towards Dead before the suicide, and his behavior afterwards. Necrobutcher ended his friendship with Euronymous. Thus, after the suicide, Mayhem was left with only two members: guitarist Euronymous and drummer Hellhammer. [[Stian Johannsen|Stian "Occultus" Johannsen]] was recruited as Mayhem's new singer and bassist. However, this was short-lived; he left the band after receiving a death threat from Euronymous. ===1991–1993=== [[File:Helvete Oslo - black metal graffiti.jpg|thumb|The basement of Euronymous' former record shop, showing graffiti from the early 1990s]] During May–June 1991,''Lords of Chaos'', p. 66. Euronymous opened a record shop named ''Helvete''{{cite web |title=Øystein 'Euronymous' Aarseth |date=June 1992 |url=http://www.angelfire.com/band/mayhem/euro2.html |accessdate=10 October 2009 |quote=''Well, the original idea was to make a specialist shop for metal in general, but that's a long time ago. Normal metal isn't very popular any more, all the children are listening to 'death' metal now. I'd rather be selling Judas Priest than Napalm Death, but at least now we can be specialized within 'death' metal and make a shop where all the trend people know that they will find all the trend music. This will help us earning money so that we can order more EVIL records to the evil people. But no matter how shitty music we have to sell, we'll make a BLACK METAL look on the shop, we've had a couple of 'actions' in churches lately, and the shop is going to look like a black church in the future. We've also thought about having total darkness inside, so that people would have to carry torches to be able to see the records.'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090909160330/http://www.angelfire.com/band/mayhem/euro2.html |archivedate=9 September 2009 |df=dmy-all }} ([[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] for "[[hell]]"){{cite web|url=http://www.dokpro.uio.no/perl/ordboksoek/ordbok.cgi?OPP=helvete&bokmaal=S%F8k+i+Bokm%E5lsordboka&ordbok=bokmaal&alfabet=n&renset=j|title=Norwegian dictionary entry for "Helvete"|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2018}} at Schweigaards gate 56 in [[Oslo]]. Norwegian black metal musicians often met in the shop's basement, including the two members of Mayhem, the members of [[Emperor (band)|Emperor]], Varg "Count Grishnackh" Vikernes of [[Burzum]], and Snorre "Blackthorn" Ruch of [[Thorns (band)|Thorns]]. Euronymous also started an independent record label called Deathlike Silence Productions, which was based at Helvete. It released albums by Norwegian bands Mayhem and Burzum, and Swedish bands [[Merciless]] and [[Abruptum]]. Euronymous, Varg,{{cite video |people=Aaron Aites (director, producer), Audrey Ewell (director, producer) |year=2009 |title=[[Until the Light Takes Us]] |url= |format= |medium=motion picture |publisher=Variance Films}} and Emperor guitarist [[Samoth|Tomas 'Samoth' Haugen]]{{cite book |last=Christe |first=Ian |title=Sound of the Beast: the Complete Headbanging History of Heavy Metal |publisher=HarperCollins Publishers Inc |year=2003 |location=New York, New York |isbn= |page=271}} all lived at Helvete at various times. Emperor drummer Faust also lived and worked there. The shop's walls were painted black and bedecked with medieval weapons, posters of bands, and [[picture disc]]s, while its window featured a polystyrene tombstone. According to Occultus, the space that Euronymous rented "was far too big and the rent was too high. That's the reason why it never did well." Only a small part of the building was used for the shop itself.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 64. Nevertheless, it became the focal point of the Norwegian black metal scene. Metalion, writer of the fanzine ''Slayer'', said that the opening of Helvete was "the creation of the whole Norwegian Black Metal scene."''Lords of Chaos'', p. 39. Daniel Ekeroth wrote in 2008,
Within just a few months [of Helvete opening], many young musicians had become obsessed with Euronymous and his ideas, and soon a lot of Norwegian death metal bands transformed into black metal bands. Amputation became Immortal, [[Thou Shalt Suffer]] turned into Emperor, and Darkthrone swapped their Swedish-inspired death metal for primitive black metal. Most notoriously, [[Old Funeral]]'s guitar player [[Varg Vikernes | Kristian (later renamed as Varg) Vikernes]] had already left the band to form his own creation, Burzum.Daniel Ekeroth: [https://books.google.com/books?id=jRRvfWp95FIC&pg=PA247&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Swedish Death Metal'']. Second printing. Brooklyn, NY: Bazillion Points 2009, p. 247.
Euronymous helped many younger bands in the scene, especially Emperor and Enslaved, both of whom he recommended to Candlelight Records.Patterson, Dayal. ''Black Metal: Evolution of the Cult''. Feral House, 2013. p.156 [[Ihsahn]] of Emperor said that "if you were trusted, if they knew you were serious in your views, you were accepted" by the Helvete scene. Euronymous "took Vikernes, who was five years younger than him, under his wing: inviting him to play bass with Mayhem and offering to release his music as Burzum".{{Cite news|url=http://www.lifedeathprizes.com/real-life-crime/oystein-aarseth-murdered-by-varg-vikernes-64542|title=What drove this black-metal star to stab his bandmate 23 times?|date=2017-09-02|work=Life Death Prizes|access-date=2017-10-02|language=en-US}}{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} However, it has been claimed that their friendship turned to rivalry. Looking back, Faust said: "It sounds really silly, but I think there was a little bit of a contest between them to see who could be more evil. It created a very difficult situation, especially for Euronymous, who wanted the glamour and the showbiz. With him, there was a lot of smoke but not so much fire". [[File:Holmenkollen kapell 0003.jpg|thumb|left|Euronymous took part in the [[Holmenkollen Chapel#Fire and reconstruction|burning of Holmenkollen Chapel]] (pictured)]] On 6 June 1992, the [[Fantoft Stave Church]] in [[Bergen]] was destroyed by [[arson]]. Vikernes is strongly suspected as the culprit but was never convicted.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 78. There followed a wave of church burnings across Norway perpetrated by musicians and fans of the Norwegian black metal scene.{{cite video |people=Grude, Torstein (director) |year=1998 |title=Satan rir Media |medium=motion picture |location=Norway |publisher=Grude, Torstein}} Euronymous was present at the burning of [[Holmenkollen Chapel]] together with Vikernes and Faust,Kristiansen, p. 261. who were convicted for the arson after Euronymous was dead. Faust says he believes that Euronymous got involved because he "felt he had to prove that he could be a part of it and not just in the background." To coincide with the release of Mayhem's ''[[De Mysteriis Dom Sathanas]]'', Vikernes and Euronymous had allegedly plotted to bomb [[Nidaros Cathedral]], which appears on the album cover. Euronymous' death in August 1993 put an end to this plan and stalled the album's release. In a 1993 interview on a Swedish radio show, Euronymous said of the church burnings:
They [Christians] must feel that there is a dark, evil power present that they have to fight, which…will make them more extreme. We also believe that when a church burns it's not only Christians who suffer, but people in general. Imagine a beautiful old stave church...what happens when it burns? The Christians feel despair, God's house is destroyed and ordinary people will suffer from grief because something beautiful was destroyed. So you end up spreading grief and despair, which is a good thing.Interview with Euronymous of Mayhem on a Swedish radio show, 1993
In January 1993, an article in one of Norway's biggest newspapers, ''[[Bergens Tidende]]'', brought the black metal scene into the media spotlight.''Lords of Chaos'', pp. 95–97. Varg Vikernes (using his pseudonym Count Grishnackh) gave an anonymous interview to a journalist from the newspaper, in which he claimed to have burnt the churches and [[Early Norwegian black metal scene#Murder of Magne Andreassen|killed a man in Lillehammer]]. According to Vikernes, the anonymous interview was planned by himself and Euronymous. The goal, he says, was to scare people, promote black metal and get more customers for Helvete.[http://www.burzum.org/eng/library/2009_interview_dagbladet.shtml "Count" Regrets Nothing]. Burzum.org. He added that the interview revealed nothing that could prove his involvement in any crime. However, by the time the article was printed, Vikernes had already been arrested. Some of the other scene members were also arrested and questioned, but all were released for lack of evidence. Vikernes himself was released in March 1993, also for lack of evidence. That month, ''[[Kerrang!]]'' published an article about the Norwegian black metal scene. In it, Euronymous and Vikernes presented themselves as leaders of a militant, cult-like group of "Satanic terrorists." Euronymous claimed that Helvete helps fund its activities, but said that he is not directly involved in its crimes, because if he was caught the organization would fall apart.''Lords of Chaos'', pp.99-101 After the ''Bergens Tidende'' episode, Euronymous decided to shut Helvete as it began to draw the attention of the police and media. Vikernes and the authors of ''Lords of Chaos'' claim that Euronymous' parents pressured him into shutting Helvete.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 120.Torstein Grude: ''[[Satan rir media]]'', 1998. ===Murder=== In early 1993, animosity arose between Euronymous and Vikernes, as well as between Euronymous and the Swedish black metal scene as a whole.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 117. On the night of 10 August 1993, Vikernes and Snorre "Blackthorn" Ruch drove from Bergen to Euronymous' apartment at Tøyengata in Oslo. Upon their arrival, a confrontation began, and Vikernes fatally stabbed Euronymous. His body was found on the stairs outside the apartment with 23 stab wounds—two to the head, five to the neck, and 16 to the back.Steinke, Darcey. "Satan's Cheerleaders". ''[[Spin (magazine)|SPIN]]''. February 1996. Euronymous' murder was initially blamed on Swedish black metallers by the media. It has been speculated{{by whom|date=February 2017}} that the murder was the result of a power struggle, a financial dispute over Burzum records, or an attempt at "outdoing" the stabbing in Lillehammer.{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/mayhem/biography/|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20130209232033/http://music.yahoo.com/mayhem/biography/|deadurl=yes|title=Mayhem Biography - Yahoo! Music|date=9 February 2013|archivedate=9 February 2013|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2018}} Vikernes denies all of these, claiming that he attacked Euronymous in self-defense. He says that Euronymous had plotted to stun him with an [[electroshock weapon]], tie him up, and [[torture]] him to death while [[snuff film|videotaping the event]]. Vikernes explains: "If he was talking about it to everybody and anybody I wouldn't have taken it seriously. But he just told a select group of friends, and one of them told me." He said Euronymous planned to use a meeting about an unsigned [[contract]] to ambush him.Vikernes, Varg: [http://www.burzum.org/eng/library/a_burzum_story02.shtml ''A Burzum Story: Part II - Euronymous'']. Burzum.org. Blackthorn stood outside smoking while Vikernes climbed the stairs to Euronymous' apartment on the fourth floor. Vikernes said he met Euronymous at the door and handed him the contract, but when he stepped forward and confronted Euronymous, Euronymous "panicked" and kicked him in the chest. The two got into a struggle and Vikernes stabbed Euronymous to death. Vikernes defends that most of Euronymous' cut wounds were caused by broken glass he had fallen on during the struggle. After the murder, Vikernes and Blackthorn drove back to Bergen. On the way, they stopped at a lake where Vikernes disposed of his bloodstained clothes. The self-defense story is doubted by Faust''Lords of Chaos'', p. 123. and other members of the scene. According to Vikernes, Blackthorn only came along to show Euronymous some new guitar riffs and was "in the wrong place at the wrong time". Blackthorn claims that, in the summer of 1993, he was almost [[Involuntary commitment|committed]] to a [[psychiatric hospital|mental hospital]] but fled to Bergen and stayed with Vikernes. He said Vikernes planned to murder Euronymous and pressured him into coming along. Blackthorn said of the murder, "I was neither for nor against it. I didn't give a shit about Øystein".''Lords of Chaos'', p. 130. Vikernes called Blackthorn's claims a "defense […] to make sure I couldn't blame him [for the murder]". ====Aftermath==== Vikernes was arrested on 19 August 1993 in Bergen. Many other members of the scene, including Blackthorn and Faust, were also taken in for questioning. The trial began on 2 May 1994. At the trial it was claimed that he, Blackthorn, and another friend had planned the murder. The third person stayed at the apartment in Bergen as an alibi. To make it look like they never left Bergen, he was to rent films, play them in the apartment, and withdraw money from Vikernes' credit card.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 129. On 16 May 1994, Vikernes was sentenced to 21 years in prison (Norway's maximum penalty) for the murder of Euronymous, the arson of three churches, the attempted arson of a fourth church, and for the theft and storage of 150 kg of explosives. However, he only confessed to the latter. Two churches were burnt the day he was sentenced, "presumably as a statement of symbolic support".''Lords of Chaos'', p. 141. Blackthorn was sentenced to 8 years in prison for being an accomplice. At Euronymous' funeral, Hellhammer (Mayhem's drummer) and Necrobutcher (Mayhem's former bassist) decided to continue with the band and worked on releasing the ''[[De Mysteriis Dom Sathanas]]'' album. Before the release, Euronymous' family asked Hellhammer to remove the bass tracks recorded by Vikernes. Hellhammer said: "I thought it was appropriate that the murderer and victim were on the same record. I put word out that I was rerecording the bass parts, but I never did." The album, which has Euronymous on electric guitar and Vikernes on bass guitar, was finally released in May 1994. A part of the Norwegian scene considered Vikernes a traitor for murdering EuronymousVarious Artists: ''Nordic Metal - A Tribute to Euronymous''. [[Necropolis Records]], 1995. and turning his back on [[Satanism]] in favor of nationalism and [[Odinism]],''Lords of Chaos'', p. 139. although Vikernes claims he was never a Satanist and had only used Satan to provoke. They saw Euronymous' death as a significant loss to the scene, and some black metallers "have sworn to avenge Aarseth's death."''Lords of Chaos'', p. 138. A few years after the murder, [[Ihsahn]] of Emperor said, "There's no discipline in the scene anymore, like earlier on around the shop."''Lords of Chaos'', p. 65. After his death, a "cult developed around the memory of Euronymous," and he was hailed by some as "the King" or "Godfather of Black Metal." A new generation of musicians also tried to gain credibility by riding on the back of his legacy. However, many of Euronymous' friends and bandmates "speak of the killing with a tone of indifference." ''Lords of Chaos'' remarks: "what is striking [...] is how little they care about the lives or deaths of one another."''Lords of Chaos'', p. 137. In the book, Hellhammer,''Lords of Chaos'', p. 136. Ihsahn and Samoth''Lords of Chaos'', p. 121. claim that Euronymous' death did not affect or at least not shock them. [[Anders Odden]] (a friend of Euronymous at the time) said of the murder: "It wasn't odd that he ended up getting killed. He thought he could threaten to kill people without it having any consequences." He added: "I think many people felt relief once he was gone." Writer and musician [[Erlend Erichsen]] agreed, saying, "Nobody was there to boss them about. The 'black metal police' were gone." ==Beliefs and personality== The book ''Lords of Chaos'' says of Euronymous:
He was always dressed in black from head to foot, his hair dyed black for added effect. He sported long, aristocratic mustaches and wore knee-high boots. His black leather biker jacket was decorated with badges [...] When talking, he seemed stern and serious, sometimes with pomposity verging on the theatrical".''Lords of Chaos'', p. 73.
In interviews, Euronymous claimed to be against [[individualism]], compassion, peace, happiness and fun. He claimed he wanted to spread hatred, sorrow and evil. In a 1992 interview, he said "The [[Hardcore punk|hardcore]] [punk] pigs have correctly made themselves guardians of morality, but we must kick them in the face and become guardians of anti-morality."''Lords of Chaos'', p. 78. The following year, he told ''Kill Yourself'' zine, "There is NOTHING which is too sick, evil or perverted" and claimed "I have no problem with killing someone in cold blood." Metalion (who knew Euronymous since 1985 and considered him his best friend)Kristiansen, pp. 266-269. said Euronymous "was always telling what he thought, following his own instincts [...] worshipping death and being extreme". Euronymous' shop attracted a lot of new young fans, many of whom looked up to and even idolized him.''Black Metal: Evolution of the Cult'', p.155 However, some who knew Euronymous claim that "the extreme Satanic image he projected was, in fact, just that — a projection which bore little resemblance to his real personality." They include [[Necrobutcher]], [[Kjetil Manheim]], Vikernes and Blackthorn.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 134. Faust said that with Euronymous, "there was a lot of smoke but not so much fire." When asked why Euronymous made such extreme statements to the press, Ihsahn said: "I think that was very much to create fear among people."''Lords of Chaos'', p. 222. He added that the scene "wanted to be in opposition to society" and "tried to concentrate more on just being 'evil' than having a real Satanic philosophy."''Lords of Chaos'', p. 218f. Mayhem drummer Kjetil Manheim (Euronymous' friend from 1983 until his death) described him as "health oriented ... A nice guy, a family guy," but said that when his older friends weren't around, "he could play out his role." Manheim claimed that Euronymous became "extreme" towards the end of his life: "He liked telling people that they were worthless; that he was the best. He was all 'I define black metal. Black metal is me!' … I think he was trapped in the image of Mayhem. He became a [[megalomaniac]]." In the documentary ''Pure Fucking Mayhem'', he said "Øystein's daily life was a total theater" that was based on the black metal "[[archetype]]" of Euronymous. ===Religion=== In interviews, Euronymous said he was a [[Theistic Satanism|theistic Satanist]].Esa Lahdenpera: {{cite web |url=http://www.fmp666.com/moonlight/mayhem.html |title=''Northern Black Metal Legends'' |accessdate=2012-02-07 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207234358/http://www.fmp666.com/moonlight/mayhem.html |archivedate=7 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}. In: ''Kill Yourself'', no. 2, August 1993. Retrieved 30 January 2013.{{cite web|url=http://smnnews.com/board/showthread.php?threadid=32213|title=Rare Euronymous interview - SMNnews Forums|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2018}} In an interview by Esa Lahdenperä conducted in August 1993, Euronymous stated:
I believe in a horned devil, a personified Satan. In my opinion all the other forms of Satanism are bullshit. [...] Satanism comes from religious Christianity, and there it shall stay. I'm a religious person and I will fight those who misuse His name. People are not supposed to believe in themselves and be individualists. They are supposed to OBEY, to be the SLAVES of religion.
The theistic Satanism espoused by Euronymous was an inversion of [[Roman Catholic]] dogma, and he claimed "We praise the evil and we believe blindly in a godly creature just like a Christian."[http://www.cultofaraluen.com/2011/euronymous-of-mayhem-1993-beat-issue-02/ Interview with Euronymous from ''Beat'', Issue 2 (1993)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130125005627/http://www.cultofaraluen.com/2011/euronymous-of-mayhem-1993-beat-issue-02/ |date=25 January 2013 }} On the [[relationship between religion and science]], he said: "Scientists can't disprove [...] religion. No matter how hard you try, you can't explain the universe. You can't leave out a religious belief." He opposed the Satanic and [[occultism|occultist]] teachings of [[Anton LaVey]] and [[Aleister Crowley]], for unlike Euronymous, they promoted what he saw as "peace" and commercial frivolity, as well as individualism in contrast to [[dogma]]. He said he would "never accept any band which preaches [[Church of Satan]] ideas, as they are just a bunch of freedom and life-loving [[Atheism|atheists]], and they stand exactly the opposite of me." When asked what he thought of Crowley's code of "[[Thelema|do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the law]]", he answered, "People shall do what WE want them to do. We're against freedom, and forced a band from Rogaland in Norway—Belsebub—to split up." As noted earlier, some of those who knew Euronymous claim that his "extreme Satanic image" was an act. While [[Mortiis]] said that Euronymous "was such a devil worshipper you wouldn't believe it,"Ian Christe: ''Sound of the Beast: the Complete Headbanging History of Heavy Metal''. New York, NY: HarperCollins, 2004. in the black metal documentary ''Until the Light Takes Us'', Varg Vikernes claimed that Euronymous was not a Satanist. He said: "To Aarseth everything was about image and he wanted to appear extreme. He wanted people to think of him as being extreme; the most extreme of them all. But he didn't want to ''be'' extreme and he wasn't ''really'' extreme." While Metalion, who was friends with both Vikernes and Euronymous when the latter died, and called Euronymous his best friend,Jon Kristiansen: ''Metalion: The Slayer Mag Diaries''. Bazillion Points Books 2011, pp. 266-269. wrote that "some people in our scene read a few books and considered themselves Satanists," he made no such statements about Euronymous.{{sfn|Kristiansen|2011|p=261f}} Tenebris (allegedly Jon NödtveidtJon Kristiansen: ''Metalion: The Slayer Mag Diaries''. Brooklyn, NY: Bazillion Points Books 2011.{{page needed|date=November 2012}}) from the [[Temple of the Black Light|Misanthropic Luciferian Order]], a Swedish Satanic order formed in 1995, wrote that "back then, in 1991, things mainly concerned black metal and ideological Satanism […] and kind of stood and fell with Euronymous and his shop. Therefore, it vanished with his death in '93".''MLO''. ''Misantropiska Lucifer Orden''. In: Jon Kristiansen: ''Metalion: The Slayer Mag Diaries''. Bazillion Points Books 2011, p. 551. Over time, some members of the Norwegian scene began to follow [[Paganism]]. Vikernes later claimed that Euronymous—"obsessed with this 'Satanist' thing"—disapproved of Vikernes promoting paganism.[http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=16250 "Updated: Burzum Leader Fails to Return After Short Leave from Prison"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201200958/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=16250 |date=1 December 2008 }}. ''[[Blabbermouth.net]]''. [[Roadrunner Records]]. 26 October 2003. Retrieved 30 January 2013. Euronymous showed no explicit disapproval of paganism though, and released the pagan band [[Enslaved (band)|Enslaved]]'s first album, ''[[Vikingligr Veldi]]'', on Deathlike Silence Productions. ===Black metal and death metal=== Euronymous said that the term "black metal" can apply to any kind of metal so long as it is "Satanic" and "heavy". He said, "If a band cultivates and worships Satan, it's black metal,"[http://www.cultofaraluen.com/2011/interview-with-euronymous-by-bard-faust-for-orcustus-fanzine-unknown/ Interview with Euronymous by Faust in ''Orcustus'' zine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140717031130/http://www.cultofaraluen.com/2011/interview-with-euronymous-by-bard-faust-for-orcustus-fanzine-unknown/ |date=17 July 2014 }} and that "in a way, it can be ordinary heavy metal or just noise. What's important is that it's Satanic; that's what makes it black metal." He rejected bands like [[Immortal (band)|Immortal]] being called black metal, "as they are not Satanists," but supported the band nonetheless. As noted earlier, bands who had [[LaVeyan Satanism|LaVeyan beliefs]] were also rejected. When it was pointed out that [[Venom (band)|Venom]] (the band that coined the term "black metal") only used Satanism as a gimmick, Euronymous said that he and the Black Circle "choose to believe otherwise."''Lords of Chaos'', p. 100. Likewise, Euronymous said that the term [[death metal]] can apply to any kind of metal, so long as the band "cultivates and worships death." Euronymous lamented the commercialization and loss of extremity within death metal. He said "Real Death Metal should be something normal people are afraid of, not something mothers can listen to," and "Death Metal is for brutal people who are capable of killing, it's not for idiotic children who want to have [a] funny hobby after school".[http://www.cultofaraluen.com/2011/euronymous-and-dead-interview-in-slayer-issue-8-1991/ Interview with Euronymous and Dead in ''Slayer'', Issue 8 (1991)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140716160423/http://www.cultofaraluen.com/2011/euronymous-and-dead-interview-in-slayer-issue-8-1991/ |date=16 July 2014 }} Like many others in the black metal scene, Euronymous originally believed that black metal should stay [[Underground music|underground]]. However, he later changed his mind. He believed that the idea of staying underground came from [[hardcore punk]], and said, "Those who scream most about being in 'underground' is also often those who make so bad music that they don't have a chance to get big themselves." He added: "I wouldn't mind making DSP big and earn a million, as long as I don't change my ways of thinking and being. […] If there were one million black metal fans in the world, most of them would be jerks, but there would be really many true and brutal people as well. The bigger we get, the more we can manipulate people into thinking like us". ===Politics=== Euronymous was interested in [[totalitarianism|totalitarian]] [[communist state]]s such as the [[History of the Soviet Union (1927–1953)|Soviet Union under Stalin]] and [[Socialist Republic of Romania|Romania]] under [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]].{{cite web|url=http://surrealdocuments.blogspot.com/2008/04/euronymous-as-kafka.html|title=Documents: Euronymous as Kafka|first=|last=Valter|date=29 April 2008|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2018}} He collected [[Eastern Bloc]] memorabilia, and in the '80s, he was a member of the Norwegian communist youth group [[Red Youth (Norway)|Rød Ungdom]], which was [[Marxism-Leninism|Marxist-Leninist]] at the time.Kevin Coogan: [http://oraclesyndicate.twoday.net/files/how+black+is+black+metal1/ ''How Black Is Black Metal'']. Retrieved 30 January 2013.''Lords of Chaos'', p. 74. He left Rød Ungdom, allegedly because he came to realise that they were "just a bunch of humanists." He said "as I HATE people I don't want them to have a good time, I'd like to see them rot under communist [[dictatorship]]." He had a fascination with the idea of [[mass surveillance]], [[secret police]] and [[forced disappearance]]. Mayhem's [[Attila Csihar]] said Euronymous was not a communist "in the political sense" but was fascinated by the power communist dictators had over their people.[http://www.lordsofmetal.nl/nl/interviews/view/id/687 Interview with Mayhem]. Lords of Metal. In a private letter written in the early '90s, Euronymous claimed that "almost all" Norwegian black metal bands at the time were "more or less Nazis," including Mayhem.[http://www.metalsucks.net/2017/01/05/editorial-regarding-euronymous-claim-that-almost-all-norwegian-bands-are-more-or-less-nazis/ Editorial: Regarding Euronymous’ Claim that “Almost ALL Norwegian Bands are More or Less Nazis”]. [[MetalSucks]]. 5 January 2017. He did not, however, use the music of Mayhem to promote any kind of politics. ==Instruments== Euronymous played a Standard sunburst [[Gibson Les Paul]] guitar, which can be seen in many pictures of him playing. He stated in various interviews that his and Mayhem's main influences were [[Venom (band)|Venom]], [[Bathory (band)|Bathory]], [[Hellhammer]], [[Sodom (band)|Sodom]] and [[Destruction (band)|Destruction]], whilst he also liked [[Iron Maiden]], [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]], [[Celtic Frost]] and [[Metallica]]. He played through a slightly modified 1981 Marshall Super Lead tube amp and used an Ibanez Tube Screamer pedal, as well as an Arion Metal Master distortion pedal.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} ==Legacy== Euronymous was ranked No. 51 out of ''The 100 Greatest Heavy Metal Guitarists of All Time'' by ''[[Guitar World]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=18446 |title=Guitar World's 100 Greatest Heavy Metal Guitarists of All Time |date=23 January 2004 |work=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |publisher=[[Roadrunner Records]] |accessdate=11 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902145402/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=18446 |archivedate=2 September 2011 |df=dmy }} In March 2012, low-cost carrier [[Norwegian Air Shuttle]] set up a public poll asking customers to pick a famous Norwegian historic figure whose picture would decorate the aircraft's tail fin. Aarseth was leading the poll, but his name was removed from the campaign after his family's request.{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.no/20120402/black-metal-stars-family-says-no-to-norwegian-tailfin-honour|title=Black metal star's family says no to Norwegian tailfin honour|date=2 April 2012|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.metalinjection.net/latest-news/bummer-alert/mayhems-euronymous-wont-be-the-face-of-norwegian-air|title=MAYHEM's Euronymous Won't Be The Face Of Norwegian Air|date=5 April 2012|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2018}} ==Discography== Euronymous played guitar on the following albums except where noted, any additional instruments or credits in notes. {| class="wikitable" |- !Band !Title !Recorded !Released !Notes |- |Mayhem |''[[:de:Pure Fucking Armageddon|Pure Fucking Armageddon]]''||1985||1985|| |- |Checker Patrol |''Metalion in the Park''||1986||1986|| |- |Mayhem |''Deathrehearsal''||1987||1987|| |- |Mayhem |''[[Deathcrush]]''||1987||1987|| |- |Mayhem |''[[Live in Leipzig]]''||1990||1993|| |- |Burzum |''Burzum''||1992||1992||Producer. Guitar solo on "War" and Gong on "Dungeons of Darkness" only. Uncredited.[http://www.burzum.org/eng/library/a_burzum_story06.shtml "A Burzum Story: Part VI - The Music"]. Burzum.org. |- |Burzum |''Det som Engang var''||1992||1993||Gong on "Den onde kysten" only. Uncredited. |- |Mayhem |''[[Dawn of the Black Hearts]]''||1990||1995||Posthumous. Cover art photograph. |- |Mayhem |''Freezing Moon/Carnage''||1990||1996||Posthumous. |- |Mayhem |''[[Out from the Dark]]''||1991||1995||Posthumous. |- |Mayhem |''[[De Mysteriis Dom Sathanas]]''||1992–1993||1994||Posthumous. |} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== * [[Michael Moynihan (journalist)|Michael Moynihan]], Didrik Søderlind: ''[[Lords of Chaos (book)|Lords of Chaos: The Bloody Rise of the Satanic Metal Underground]]'' (Revised and Expanded Edition). Feral House, 2003. ==External links== * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013011424/http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/euro-necro-damageinc.htm |date=13 October 2007 |title=Euronymous and Necro Butcher interview from ''Damage Inc'' zine No. 1 circa 1986 }} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013034900/http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/euro-morbidmag8.htm |date=13 October 2007 |title=Interview from ''Morbid Mag'' no. 8 }} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013011418/http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/euro-killyourself2.htm |date=13 October 2007 |title=Interview by Esa Lahdenpera, from ''Kill Yourself!!! Magazine'' no. 4 }} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009210111/http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/euro-dead-slayer8.htm |date=9 October 2007 |title=Euronymous and Dead interview from ''Slayer'' no. 8 }} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013011413/http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/euro-closeup.htm |date=13 October 2007 |title=Interview from ''Close-Up'' magazine }} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823101907/http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/euro-badfaust.htm |date=23 August 2007 |title=Interview from ''Orcustus'' fanzine }} * [http://euronymous.ru/ Russian Euronymous fan site] {{Mayhem (band)}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:Crimes involving Satanism or the occult]] [[Category:Deaths by stabbing in Norway]] [[Category:Mayhem (band) members]] [[Category:Murdered Norwegian musicians]] [[Category:Murder in 1993]] [[Category:Norwegian black metal musicians]] [[Category:Norwegian businesspeople]] [[Category:Norwegian communists]] [[Category:Norwegian murder victims]] [[Category:Norwegian rock guitarists]] [[Category:Norwegian Satanists]] [[Category:Norwegian Sami people]] [[Category:People from Egersund]] [[Category:People murdered in Norway]] [[Category:Black metal guitarists]] [[Category:20th-century guitarists]]

Chairman, [[Zodiac Maritime|Zodiac Group]] Chairman, Global Holdings{{cite web|title=Eyal Ofer|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/eyal-ofer/|website=Forbes|accessdate=17 April 2015}} and Chairman, Eyal & Marilyn Ofer Family Foundation{{cite web|title=Eyal Ofer Family Foundation gives £10 million towards Tate Modern’s new development|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/about/press-office/press-releases/eyal-ofer-family-foundation-gives-ps10-million-towards-tate|website=tate.org.uk|accessdate=15 March 2017}} | salary = | networth = [[United States dollar|US$]]9.4 billion (August 2018){{cite web|title=Eyal Ofer|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/eyal-ofer/|website=Forbes|accessdate=18 January 2018}} | spouse = Marilyn Ofer | parents = [[Sammy Ofer]]
Aviva Ofer | children = 4 | relatives = [[Yuli Ofer]] (uncle)
[[Idan Ofer]] (younger brother){{cite web |url=http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/top100/article453177.ece |title=Eyal Ofer, Zodiac Group |publisher=Lloyd's List |accessdate=23 April 2015}} | website = }} '''Eyal Ofer''' (born 1950) is a [[Monaco]]-based Israeli [[billionaire]] real estate and shipping magnate, and a philanthropist. He is the chairman of Ofer Global, [[Zodiac Maritime|Zodiac Group]] and Global Holdings. ==Early life== Eyal Ofer was born in 1950 in [[Haifa]], Israel.Karmin, Craig. [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324031404578479253519720418 Developers Team Up With a Man Behind the Scenes], ''The Wall Street Journal'', May 12, 2013 His father, [[Sammy Ofer]], was a Romanian-born Israeli shipping magnate and once Israel's richest man.Pickford, James. [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/73bfec0c-e32f-11e2-bd87-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3SekS8nmf Eyal Ofer donates £10m to Tate Modern extension], ''Financial Times'', July 2, 2013Starkman, Rotem; Georgi, Anat. [http://www.haaretz.com/be-smart-work-hard-and-be-born-into-the-right-family-1.243231 Be smart, work hard - and be born into the right family], ''Haaretz'', April 3, 2008 Eyal graduated from [[Atlantic College]], an international boarding school affiliated with the [[United World Colleges]], based in [[St Donat's Castle]], [[Wales]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=651785&ticker=RCL |title=List of Public Companies Worldwide |website=Bloomberg.com |date= |accessdate=7 December 2015}} In his teenage years, he spent summers working on the family company's ships, loading cargo, scraping the boats' sides and repainting them, as well as traveling to international ports. He served as an intelligence officer in the [[Israeli Air Force]] from 1967 to 1973. He then studied Law in [[London]]. ==Career== Ofer's business interests are concentrated in shipping, cruise lines and global real estate within the Ofer Global group,{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/billionaires/profile/eyal-ofer |publisher=Bloomberg Billionaires |title=Bloomberg Billionaires: Eyal Ofer |accessdate=16 March 2015}} a Monaco-based private company focused on shipping, real estate, oil and gas, banking and investments in Europe, North America, the Near East and Asia.{{cite web|url=http://www.oferglobal.com/about/ |title=About Ofer Global |website=Oferglobal.com |date= |accessdate=7 December 2015}} According to ''[[Forbes]]'', Ofer has a net worth of $9.5 billion, as of March 2016. In 2014, he received an honorary lifetime membership of the [[Baltic Exchange]] in London in recognition of his contribution to shipping in the UK and global maritime trade. Other recipients of this award have included the Duke of Edinburgh, Winston Churchill, and [[Mærsk Mc-Kinney Møller|Maersk Mc-Kinney]].[http://www.allaboutshipping.co.uk/2014/07/10/baltic-exchange-awards-honorary-life-membership-to-eyal-ofer/ "Baltic Exchange awards honorary life membership to Eyal Ofer"], ''All About Shipping'', 10 July 2014. Accessed 5 November 2015. In 2016, Lloyd’s List named him number 10 in the top 100 most influential people in the shipping industry.{{cite web|title=Top 100 Most Influential People in the Shipping Industry|url=https://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/top100/article544954.ece|website=Lloydslist.com|accessdate=1 March 2017}} He is a frequent speaker at industry events, including the [[Milken Institute]] Global Conference in 2012, 2013 and 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.milkeninstitute.org/events/conferences/global-conference/2012/speaker-detail/8686 |title=Global Conference 2012 | Eyal Ofer |publisher=Milken Institute |date= |accessdate=7 December 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.milkeninstitute.org/events/conferences/global-conference/2013/speaker-detail/11611 |title=Global Conference 2013 | Eyal Ofer |publisher=Milken Institute |date= |accessdate=7 December 2015}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://thebalticbriefing.com/2015/09/08/downing-street-welcomes-shipping-leaders/ |title=Downing Street welcomes shipping leaders |website=Thebalticbriefing.com |date=8 September 2015 |accessdate=7 December 2015}}[http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20081029005297/en/Real-Estate-Titans-Global-Investors-Convene-KnowledgeWharton "Real Estate Titans and Global Investors Convene at Knowledge@Wharton Forum to Address How Emerging Economies Are Coping with the Credit Crisis"], ''Business Wire'', 29 October 2008. Accessed 5 November 2015. Ofer also regularly attends the [[World Economic Forum]]’s annual meeting in Davos.{{cite web|last1=Pendleton|first1=Devon|last2=Benmeleh|first2=Yaacov|title=One Winner, One Loser in Brothers’ Lottery Worth Billions|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-04/one-winner-one-loser-in-brothers-lottery-worth-billions|website=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=1 March 2017}} In 2018, Ofer joined the Advisory Board of the Bloomberg New Economy Forum.{{cite web |title=Bloomberg’s First-Ever New Economy Forum in Singapore |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/company/announcements/400-worlds-influential-business-government-leaders-attend-bloombergs-first-ever-new-economy-forum-singapore-november-6-7-2018/ |website=Bloomberg |accessdate=22 November 2018}} The board is made up of a group of leaders in their fields from business, government, education and philanthropy including David Rubenstein, Gary Cohn and Mukesh Ambani.{{cite web |title=New Economy Forum In Singapore To Address Business Challenges - CXOtoday.com |url=http://www.cxotoday.com/story/new-economy-forum-in-singapore-to-address-business-challenges/ |website=cxotoday |accessdate=22 November 2018}} ===Property=== Ofer first moved to New York City in 1980 to start the family real estate business, and invested in properties on [[Park Avenue]] South, which he rented to law firms and public relations firms through his real estate company, Global Holdings. Over the years, he assembled a real estate empire having acquired a deep knowledge of ships which had made him comfortable with managing similarly tangible assets. Ofer is the chairman of Global Holdings, a private real estate holding company specializing in large-scale commercial real estate and high-end residential developments. Its holdings include prime commercial properties in Manhattan, and a controlling stake in Miller Global Properties, a large real estate investment fund focusing on key markets in North America and Europe.[http://realestate.wharton.upenn.edu/meetings/spring2015/agenda.php?speaker=11 "Eyal Ofer"], ''Wharton University of Pennsylvania'', Accessed 21 October 2015. He serves as Miller Global's co-chairman.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalholdingsinc.com/ |title=US-based real estate investment company |publisher=Global Holdings, Inc. |date= |accessdate=7 December 2015}} Global Holdings' commercial projects include, among others, and 120 Park Avenue – the former headquarters of the [[Altria Group]].Brown, Eliot. [http://observer.com/2007/11/120-park-avenue-sells-for-525-m/ "120 Park Avenue Sells for $525 M"], ''Observer'', 13 November 2007. Accessed 21 October 2015. Its residential projects include [[15 Central Park West]], which was described as “the most powerful apartment building in the world” and “the most lucrative”, with quoted apartment sales of approximately $2 billion.{{cite web|url=http://therealdeal.com/research/topics/property/15-central-park-west/ |title=15 Central Park West | The Real Deal New York |website=Therealdeal.com |date=7 February 2012 |accessdate=7 December 2015}}{{cite web|last=Goldberger |first=Paul |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2008/09/centralparkwest200809 |title=The King of Central Park West |publisher=Vanity Fair |date=31 August 2008 |accessdate=7 December 2015}} It was the subject of a book published in March 2014 by Michael Gross entitled "House of Outrageous Fortune: Fifteen Central Park West, the World’s Most Powerful Address".{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/books-and-arts/21599328-what-manhattan-apartment-block-tells-us-about-american-economy-boom-view |title=Boom with a view |publisher=The Economist |date=22 March 2014 |accessdate=7 December 2015}} They also include the development at The Greenwich Lane (in partnership with the [[Jack Rudin|Rudin family]] - formerly the site of [[Saint Vincent's Catholic Medical Center]]), together with the redevelopment of [[18 Gramercy Park|18 Gramercy Park South]], 520 Park Avenue and [[50 United Nations Plaza]] (all in partnership with Zeckendorf Development).Carlyle, Erin. [https://www.forbes.com/sites/erincarlyle/2014/09/24/manhattans-new-most-expensive-listing-a-130-million-park-avenue-penthouse/ "Manhattan's New Most Expensive Listing: A $130 Million Park Avenue Penthouse"], ''Forbes'', 24 September 2014. Accessed 11 November 2015. 18 Gramercy Park South (ranked the most expensive Manhattan development in 2013)Finn, Robin. [http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/09/13/big-ticket-gramercy-park-penthouse-for-42-million/?_r=0 "Big Ticket - Gramercy Park Penthouse for $42 Million"], ''The New York Times'', 13 September 2013. Accessed 17 March 2016. and 15 Central Park West were designed by architect [[Robert A. M. Stern]].{{cite web|last=Voien |first=Guelda |url=http://therealdeal.com/blog/2014/01/07/18-gramercy-park-ranked-highest-priced-new-project-of-2013/ |title=18 Gramercy Park ranked highest-priced new project of 2013 |website=Therealdeal.com |date=7 January 2014 |accessdate=7 December 2015}} 50 UN Plaza is a 44-story tower designed by London-based architects [[Foster and Partners]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/27/realestate/norman-foster-enjoys-a-new-york-moment.html|title=Norman Foster Enjoys a New York Moment|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=7 December 2015}}{{cite web|author=Oshrat Carmiel |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-06-06/nyc-s-zeckendorfs-embrace-global-buyers-with-un-condos |title=NYC’s Zeckendorfs Embrace Global Buyers With UN Condos |website=Bloomberg.com |date=6 June 2013 |accessdate=7 December 2015}} Today, Ofer’s portfolio includes more than 50 properties in four countries. ===Shipping=== Ofer started his career in international maritime transportation in all the major shipping segments in the 1980s. He is the chairman of [[Zodiac Maritime|Zodiac Group]], a privately held Monaco-based shipping company with a fleet of more than 150 vessels. It is the largest operator of vessels under the Red Ensign by tonnage.[http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/sector/regulation/article69732.ece "Zodiac signals its commitment to the Red Ensign"], ''Lloyds List'', 22 March 2010. Accessed 21 October 2015. Ofer has been a director of [[Royal Caribbean Cruises]], the second largest cruise company in the world, since May 1995 and holds a significant stake in the company.{{cite web|url=http://www.rclinvestor.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=103045&p=irol-govBio&ID=6817 |title=Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. : Investor Relations : Biography |website=Rclinvestor.com |date=23 October 2015 |accessdate=7 December 2015}} In 2016, Ofer was ranked 10th in the [[Lloyd’s List]] Top 100 Most Influential People in the Shipping Industry. According to Lloyd’s List, “the consensus view from those who know Eyal Ofer best is that he is a man who understands the markets with forensic detail”.{{cite web|title=Top 100 Most Influential People in the Shipping Industry|url=https://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/top100/article544954.ece|website=Lloydslist.com|accessdate=23 February 2017}} Ofer is said to control the 20th biggest fleet in the world. === Energy === Through O.G. Oil & Gas, the oil and gas arm of Ofer Global's O.G. Energy division, Ofer has exploration and production interests in the Australasia and South East Asia region. In 2017, O.G. Oil & Gas made a partial takeover offer for a majority stake in New Zealand Oil & Gas, which resulted in it acquiring nearly 70% of the company.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nz-oil-gas-m-a/o-g-oil-gas-intends-to-buy-majority-stake-in-new-zealand-oil-gas-idUSKCN1BS0X2|title=O.G. Oil & Gas intends to buy majority stake in New Zealand Oil & Gas|last1=Resnick-Ault|first1=Jessica|website=reuters.com|accessdate=2 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.skynews.com.au/business/business/company/2017/09/19/second-takeover-offer-for-nzog.html|title=Second takeover offer for NZOG|website=skynews.com.au|accessdate=2 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11923645|title=Partial takeover offer for NZOG|website=nzherald.co.nz|accessdate=2 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nbr.co.nz/article/zetas-partial-bid-nzog-trumped-smaller-shareholder-ogog-b-207524|title=Zeta's partial bid for NZOG trumped by smaller shareholder OGOG|last1=McBeth|first1=Paul|website=nbr.co.nz|accessdate=2 October 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/offshore/1465169/eyal-ofer-secures-upstream-entry-into-lng-with-new-zealand-oil-and-gas-deal|title=Eyal Ofer secures upstream entry into LNG with New Zeal|last=|first=|date=2018-04-05|work=TradeWinds|access-date=2018-08-23|language=en}} In October 2018, O.G. Energy agreed to acquire a 40 per cent stake in Beach Energy’s Otway Basin assets off the south east coast of Australia.{{cite web |title=Beach Energy deal brings Israeli billionaire into Australian gas |url=https://www.afr.com/business/energy/oil/beach-energy-deal-brings-israeli-billionaire-into-australian-gas-20181005-h169kc |website=AFR |accessdate=22 November 2018}} Ofer is also the principal of [[OMNI Offshore Terminals]], the largest provider of floating production storage and offloading (FSO & FPSO) assets to the offshore oil and gas industry. Founded in 1990, the Singapore–headquartered company has delivered 23 conversion projects, 2 FPSO and 21 FSO.{{cite web |url=http://totalworldenergy.net/omni-offshore-terminals/ |title=Omni Offshore Terminals |publisher=Total World Energy |accessdate=16 March 2015}} === Technology === Ofer has interests in technology companies through O.G. Tech Ventures, the tech investment arm of Ofer Global.{{cite web|title=Canaan Partners Joins $9M Funding for Arbe Robotics|url=http://citybizlist.com/article/450883/canaan-partners-joins-9m-funding-for-arbe-robotics|website=citybizlist.com|accessdate=11 January 2018}} O.G. Tech Ventures is a [[venture capital fund]] launched in 2017 focusing on [[Start-ups|early growth start-ups]] with [[disruptive technologies]]. In January 2018, the fund participated in the [[Series B]] funding round of [[Bringg]], a delivery logistics platform for enterprises.{{cite web|last1=Perez|first1=Sarah|title=Delivery logistics platform Bringg raises $12M from strategic investors, including Salesforce Ventures|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/01/16/delivery-logistics-platform-bringg-raises-12m-from-strategic-investors-including-salesforce-ventures/|website=techcrunch.com|accessdate=19 January 2018}} This follows the fund's participation in the November 2017 funding round of Arbe Robotics, a Tel Aviv startup developing a high-resolution radar system for [[Self driving cars|self-driving cars]].{{cite web|last1=Lunden|first1=Ingrid|title=Arbe Robotics raises $9M to build high-resolution radars for autonomous cars|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/11/02/arbe-robotics-raises-9m-to-build-high-resolution-radars-for-autonomous-cars/|website=TechCrunch|accessdate=11 January 2018|language=en}} It has also invested in enSilo and Secdo, companies which offer cybersecurity and data protection services, as well as ClipCall which brings technology to home maintenance and improvement.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/arbe-robotics-raises-9m-for-self-driving-radar-systems-funding/|title=Arbe Robotics Raises $9M For Self-Driving Radar Systems Funding - HybridCars.com|date=2017-11-02|work=HybridCars.com|access-date=2018-01-10|language=en-US}}{{cite web|title=Investors - Roy Oron|url=https://signal.nfx.com/investors/roy-oron|website=signal.nfx.com|accessdate=19 January 2018}} === Art === Ofer has built up a significant collection of contemporary and modern art, having also inherited half of his father's "vast collection". In December 2013, Ofer donated £1.5m to the [[National Maritime Museum]] to allow it to keep two 18th-century [[George Stubbs]] paintings (Portrait of a Large Dog and The Kongouro from New Holland) in the UK after a public appeal by [[David Attenborough]].[https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-24826579 "George Stubbs' kangaroo and dingo paintings to stay in UK"], ''BBC News Online; Entertainment & Arts'', 6 November 2013. Retrieved 17 April 2015. In 2013, Ofer also gave a major gift of £10 million to support the completion of the development of [[Tate Modern]], a museum of modern art based in London.Mark Brown, [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2013/jul/02/tate-modern-gift-eyal-ofer Tate Modern receives £10m gift from Israeli shipping magnate Eyal Ofer], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 2 July 2013Ellie Armon Azoulay, [http://www.haaretz.com/business/.premium-1.533805 Israeli tycoon Eyal Ofer donates £10 million to London's Tate Modern], ''[[Haaretz]]'', 04.07.2013 As a result, the exhibition gallery on the third floor bears his name. The space has housed many significant exhibitions, including [[Matisse]], [[Picasso]], [[Edward Hopper]] and [[Gauguin]].{{cite web|last1=Andrews|first1=Michael|title=Israeli Shipping Billionaire Eyal Ofer Donates £10 Million to the Tate Modern Art Gallery London|url=http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2013/07/07/israeli-shipping-billionaire-eyal-ofer-donates-10-million-to-the-tate-modern-art-gallery-london/|website=jewishbusinessnews.com|accessdate=24 February 2017}} In 2018, the “Eyal Ofer Galleries” are set to hold Tate Modern’s first ever solo exhibition of Pablo Picasso’s work, “Picasso 1932 – Love, Fame, Tragedy”, which will display the artist’s masterpiece “La Reve” (sold for a record £102 million) along with more than 100 “outstanding” paintings, sculptures and drawings. The exhibition is described by the Tate as one of the most significant in its history.{{cite web|last1=Singh|first1=Anita|title=Picasso exhibition: Tate Modern planning 'blockbuster' in 2018|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/29/picasso-exhibition-tate-modern-planning-blockbuster-2018/|website=telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=24 February 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Mark|title=Tate Modern to host 'once in a lifetime' Picasso exhibition|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/jan/30/tate-modern-picasso-exhibition-affair-lover-marie-therese-walter|website=theguardian.com|accessdate=24 February 2017}} ==Philanthropy== Ofer is a supporter of artistic, educational and cultural institutions – including the Tate Modern and the National Maritime Museum in the UK – through the Eyal & Marilyn Ofer Family Foundation, which continues his family's philanthropic tradition.Pendleton, Devon. [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-07-04/israeli-billionaire-ofer-makes-gift-to-expand-tate-modern "Israeli Billionaire Ofer Makes Gift to Expand Tate Modern"], ''Bloomberg Business'', July 4, 2013. Accessed 21 October 2015. Ofer is chairman of the Foundation.{{cite web|title=Eyal Ofer Family Foundation gives £10 million towards Tate Modern’s new development|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/about/press-office/press-releases/eyal-ofer-family-foundation-gives-ps10-million-towards-tate|website=tate.org.uk|accessdate=15 March 2017}} Eyal was one of the donors to the [[Gloriana (barge)|Gloriana]] during the [[Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II]] in 2012. Through his family Foundation, in 2013, he donated £10 million to Tate Modern, and £1.5m to the National Maritime Museum. ==Personal life== He is married to Marilyn Ofer, and they have four children.{{cite web|url=https://www.oferfamilyfoundation.org/|website=oferfamilyfoundation.org|title=Eyal & Marilyn Ofer Family Foundation|accessdate=1 August 2017}} They reside in Monte Carlo, Monaco. In 2008, they resided in west London and had a home in [[Herzliya Pituah]] near [[Tel Aviv]]. He also owns an apartment at 15 Central Park West, a building he developed located on the [[Upper West Side]] of Manhattan in New York City. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://www.oferglobal.com/eyal-ofer/ Official website] * [https://www.og-tech.vc/ O.G. Tech Ventures] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ofer, Eyal}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Haifa]] [[Category:People from Herzliya]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:People from London]] [[Category:People from Monte Carlo]] [[Category:People educated at Atlantic College]] [[Category:Israeli Air Force personnel]] [[Category:Israeli expatriates in Monaco]] [[Category:Israeli businesspeople]] [[Category:Israeli philanthropists]] [[Category:Israeli billionaires]] [[Category:Jewish philanthropists]] [[Category:Israeli people of Romanian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Ofer family]]

{{About|a plantation in Brazil|the Ministry of Finance at times called "(Ministry of) Fazenda", in Brazil|Ministry of Finance (Brazil)|the same in Portugal|Ministry of Finance (Portugal)}} {{refimprove|article|date=January 2012}} [[File:Fazenda Piedade.jpg|thumb|350px|Piedade farm. The [[Casa-grande|master's house]] of a coffee plantation founded in the 18th century in [[Paty do Alferes]] in the Province (now State) of Rio de Janeiro.]]
A '''fazenda''' is a plantation found throughout Brazil; during the colonial period (16th - 18th centuries) they were concentrated primarily in the northeastern region, where (sugar) was produced, expanding during the 19th century in the southeastern region to [[coffee]] production. Fazenda now denotes any kind of [[farm]].
Fazendas created major export commodities for Brazilian trade, but also led to intensification of [[slavery in Brazil]]. Coffee provided a new basis for agricultural expansion in southern Brazil. In the provinces of Rio de Janeiro and then São Paulo, coffee estates, or ''fazendas'', began to spread toward the interior as new lands were opened.<ref name="chambers1879">{{Cite book | publisher = W. & R. Chambers | volume = 56 | pages = 823–824 | last = Chambers | first = William |author2=Robert Chambers | title = Chambers's journal of popular literature, science, and art | chapter = Slave-life in Brazil | location = London | date = 1879-12-27 | chapterurl = https://books.google.com/books?id=-9wXAQAAIAAJ&dq=fazenda%20slavery&pg=PA823#v=onepage&q&f=true }}</ref> By 1850, coffee made up more than 50% of Brazil's [[exports]], and more than half of world coffee production.<ref name="baronov2000">{{Cite book | publisher = Greenwood Publishing Group | isbn = 978-0-313-31242-7 | last = Baronov | first = David | title = The abolition of slavery in Brazil: the "liberation" of Africans through the emancipation of capital | year = 2000 | page = 183 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=JdbNzvZvBpkC&lpg=PA183&dq=slavery%20in%20brazil%20coffee&pg=PA183#v=onepage&q&f=false }}</ref>
== Effects ==
Along with the expansion of coffee growing came an intensification of [[slavery in Brazil]], as the country's primary form of labor. More than 1.4 million [[Ethnic groups of Africa|Africans]] were forced to be slaves in Brazil in the last 50 years of the slave trade, and even after the [[trans-Atlantic slave trade]] ended, slavery continued until 1888.<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Duke University Press | isbn = 978-0-8223-0888-1 | others = Rebecca Jarvis Scott (ed.) | title = The Abolition of slavery and the aftermath of emancipation in Brazil | date = 1988-09-01 }}</ref>
Because of the increased profit from the trade of coffee, the years after 1850 saw considerable growth and prosperity in Brazil. [[Dom Pedro II]] proved to be willing to expand economic prosperity, even if that prosperity was based on slave labor.{{clarify|date=January 2014}} [[Railroad]]s, [[steamship]]s and the [[telegraph]] were introduced to Brazil, all paid for by the money the fazendas supplied from their coffee crop. In growing cities such as [[Rio de Janeiro]] and [[São Paulo]], merchants, lawyers, a middle class, and an urban working class grew, once again paid for by the money coming from the fazendas.
